Dieological gluing of vector pseudo-bundles and pseudo-metrics
on them
Ekaterina Pervova
August 24, 2018
Abstract
Although our main interest here is developing an appropriate analog, for dieological vector pseudo-
bundles, of a Riemannian metric, a signicant portion is dedicated to continued study of the gluing
operation for pseudo-bundles introduced in [9]. We give more details regarding the behavior of this
operation with respect to gluing, also providing some details omitted from [9], and pay more attention
to the relations with the spaces of smooth maps. We also show that a usual smooth vector bundle
over a manifold that admits a nite atlas can be seen as a result of a dieological gluing, and thus
deduce that its usual dual bundle is the same as its dieological dual. We then consider the notion of a
pseudo-metric, the fact that it does not always exist (which seems to be related to non-local-triviality
condition), construction of an induced pseudo-metric on a pseudo-bundle obtained by gluing, and
nally, the relation between the spaces of all pseudo-metrics on the factors of a gluing, and on its
result. We conclude by commenting on the induced pseudo-metric on the pseudo-bundle dual to the
given one.

Introduction
For anyone who comes into contact with dieology [6] (meant initially as an extension of dierential
geometry, although as of now, other opinions exist) it does not take long to notice that a great number
of typical objects do not admit obvious counterparts; there is obviously a dieological space as the base
object, and there are also various types of it endowed with an extra, algebraic, structure, starting with a
natural concept of a dieological vector space and proceeding towards the notion of a dieological group,
dieological algebra, and so on. But when we try to endow these objects with further structures, even
very simple ones, we discover that it is not possible to do so.
The specic instance that we have in mind at the moment is that of a scalar product on a nite-
dimensional dieological vector space. Surprising in its simplicity, it excellently illustrates what has been
said in the previous paragraph. Specically, it has been known for some time (see [6], Ex. 70 on p. 74)
that a nite-dimensional dieological vector space admits a smooth (with respect to its dieology) scalar
product if and only if it is a standard space, which means that, as a vector space, it is isomorphic to
Rn for some n, and its dieology consists of all usual smooth maps. But for a single vector space this
issue is easily resolved: one looks (as was done, for instance, in [8]) for a kind of minimally degenerate
smooth symmetric bilinear form on it; there is always one, of rank equal to the dimension of the so-called
dieological dual [15] of the space in question.
The next natural step, then, is to pose the same question for a possible dieological counterpart of
the notion of a Riemannian metric. The corresponding issues become two-fold then: for one thing, there
is not yet a standard theory of tangent spaces in dieology (but some constructions do exist, see, for
instance, [2], as well as the previous [4], and other references therein), so we are left with looking for a
dieological version of a dieological metric on an abstract (dieological version of) vector bundle.
This version appeared originally in [5] (by the authors own admission, the same material is better
explained in Chapter 8 of [6]; but the former is the original source). It was later utilized in [14], under
the name of a regular vector bundle, and then in [2], where it is called a dieological vector space over
X, X being the notation for the base space. We call it a dieological vector pseudo-bundle, as was
already done in [9]. This concept is an obvious (it is asked that all the operations be smooth in the
dieological sense) extension to the dieological context of the usual notion of a vector bundle, except
that there is no requirement of local triviality. This allows to treat objects that not only carry an unusual
smooth structure (that is, a dieology) but also ones that, from a topological point of view, have a more
complicated local structure than that of a Euclidean space.
For objects such as these, there are well-dened notions of the tensor product pseudo-bundle and of
the dual pseudo-bundle, see [14]. So a dieological metric can of course be dened as a smooth section
of the tensor product of two duals, symmetric at each point. However, due to what has been said about
single vector spaces, the value at a given point cannot, in general, be a scalar product, unless the bre at
this specic point is standard (generally not the case). In this paper we discuss what happens if pointwise
we try to take the minimally degenerate value of the prospective section (the approach initiated in [9]).

1.1 Dieological spaces
The basic notion for dieology is that of a dieological space, that is, a set endowed with a dieology, a
collection of maps called plots that play the role of a (version of a) smooth structure.
Dieological spaces and smooth maps between them A dieological space is just a set X endowed
with a dieology, which is a collection of maps from usual domains to X; three natural conditions must
be satised.
Denition 1.1. ([12]) A dieological space is a pair (X, DX ) where X is a set and DX is a specied
collection, also called the dieology of X, of maps U  X (called plots) for each open set U in Rn and

satised:
1. (The covering condition) Every constant map U  X is a plot;
2. (The smooth compatibility condition) If U  X is a plot and V  U is a smooth map (in the usual
sense) then the composition V  U  X is also a plot;
3. (The sheaf condition) If U = iUi is an open cover and U  X is a set map such that each
restriction Ui  X is a plot then the entire map U  X is a plot as well.
A standard example of a dieological space is a standard manifold whose dieology consists of all
usual smooth maps into it. However, some standard constructions of dieology (appearing shortly below)
allow us to construct plenty of unusual dieological spaces.

1.2 Dieological vector spaces
Here we turn to the concept of a dieological vector space (mostly, we speak about nite-dimensional
ones, although various denitions apply elsewhere).
1.2.1 Main denitions
All the main concepts regarding vector spaces admit their dieological counterparts, usually by a trivial
extension, although sometimes with non-trivial implications.
A dieological vector space A dieological vector space is a (real) vector space V endowed with
a vector space dieology, that is, any dieology for which the following two maps are smooth: the
addition map V  V  V , where obviously (v1, v2) 7 v1 + v2 and V  V carries the product dieology,
and the scalar multiplication map R  V  V , where R carries the standard dieology and, once again,
R  V carries the product dieology. All our spaces are nite-dimensional.
Fine dieology The set of all vector space dieologies on a given vector space V is quite large (although
there are quite a few dieologies that are not vector dieologies1). The nest of them is called the ne
dieology, and a vector space endowed with its ne dieology is called a ne vector space.
Subspaces and quotient spaces Any vector subspace W 6 V of a dieological vector space V is
itself a dieological vector space for the subset dieology; the latter is therefore the canonical dieology
on W , and unless specied otherwise, any subspace is automatically considered with its subset dieology.
Likewise, the usual quotient space V /W is a dieological vector space for the quotient dieology; it is
canonically endowed with the latter.
Linear maps and smooth linear maps Surprisingly at least for a nite-dimensional case (this is
my opinion), a dieological vector space in general admits linear maps that are not smooth. More
precisely, for every linear map to be smooth a nite-dimensional space must necessarily be standard,
that is, dieomorphic to the standard Rn for the appropriate n. As an illustration, we add a simple
example: if V is identied with Rn as a vector space and V carries the vector space dieology generated
by the plot R  x  |x|en (in place of |x| we could take any not-everywhere-smooth function) then the
corresponding dual (in the usual sense) function en : V  R is not smooth (for the chosen dieology of
V and the standard dieology of R).
Dieological dual The above example also shows that the so-called dieological dual ([14], [15]) of
a dieological vector space (of nite dimension) has in general smaller dimension than the space itself.
The dieological dual V  of V is the space of all smooth R-valued linear maps on V ; it is not hard to
nd examples of spaces with trivial dieological dual and not-too-large a dieology. Indeed, it suces
to extend the example that appears in the preceding paragraph, endowing Rn with the vector space
dieology generated by the n plots R  x  |x|ei for i = 1, . . . , n. No element ei of the canonical dual
basis of Rn is smooth for this dieology, so the dieological dual is trivial in this case, although the
dieology in question is a rather specic one.
Euclidean structure and pseudo-metrics A scalar product on a dieological vector space V is a
usual scalar product on the underlying vector space which is also smooth with respect to the dieology
of V . However (see [6]), in the nite-dimensional case this concept does not make much sense, meaning
that unless V is a standard space, it does not carry any scalar product; in other words, if V is nite-
dimensional and is not dieomorphic to some standard Rn then every smooth symmetric bilinear form
on V is degenerate. The degree of degeneracy, unsurprisingly, is measured by the dierence between
the dimension of V and that of its dieological dual; that is to say, the maximal rank that a smooth
symmetric bilinear form on V might have is dim(V ). It is easy to see that this rank is always achieved;
any smooth symmetric bilinear form on V of rank dim(V ) is called a pseudo-metric on V .

1.3 Dieological vector pseudo-bundles
We now turn to the object which is central to our discussion. Indeed, although a notion of metric (or
its best-possible substitute, as in our case) would usually be dened on some kind of a tangent bundle,
there is not yet a standard theory of such for dieological spaces, although there do exist various ad
hoc treatments and proposals; in particular, the notion of the internal tangent bundle (see [2]) is now
emerging prominently. Our solution to this matter is to consider a dieological notion of a metric (that
we call a pseudo-metric), or whatever can reasonably be considered such, on abstract dieological vector
pseudo-bundles, on the assumption that whatever a proper notion of a tangent bundle for a dieological
space would reveal itself to be, it should be an instance of such a pseudo-bundle.
